title: Dan Kriel
text:
Daniel David Kriel (born 15 February 1994) is a South African professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player for the in <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> and in the <a href="Currie%20Cup">Currie Cup</a> and in the <a href="Rugby%20Challenge%20%28South%20Africa%29">Rugby Challenge</a>. His regular position is centre. Kriel is the twin brother of professional rugby player <a href="Jesse%20Kriel">Jesse Kriel</a>.
Career.
Schools rugby (2010–12).
Kriel attended <a href="Maritzburg%20College">Maritzburg College</a> in <a href="Pietermaritzburg">Pietermaritzburg</a> and was selected to represent KwaZulu-Natal at the Under-16 Grant Khomo Week competition in 2010. He missed out on selection for their Under-18 <a href="Craven%20Week">Craven Week</a> two years later after suffering a dislocated shoulder prior to the competition.
Blue Bulls (2013).
After high school, Kriel moved to <a href="Pretoria">Pretoria</a> to join the Academy. He was the first-choice outside centre for the side in the <a href="2013%20Under-19%20Provincial%20Championship">2013 Under-19 Provincial Championship</a>, starting eleven of their fourteen matches in the competition. He scored six tries for the Blue Bulls during the competition, which included a brace in their 46–16 victory over . The Blue Bulls topped the log, winning all twelve of their matches during the competition. Kriel started both their 37–21 defeat of in the semi-final and the final, where the Blue Bulls won 35–23 to win the title and go through the entire competition undefeated.
Blue Bulls / South Africa Under-20 (2014).
In 2014, Kriel was called up to the <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">South African Under-20</a> team that participated at the <a href="2014%20IRB%20Junior%20World%20Championship">2014 IRB Junior World Championship</a> in <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. He didn't play in South Africa's first match, a 61–5 victory over <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a>, but he started their second match of the competition, helping South Africa to a 33–24 victory over hosts <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a>, as well as their final pool match which saw them beat <a href="Samoa%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a> 21–8 to finish top of their pool. Kriel was named on the bench as South Africa once again met <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a> in the semi-finals and helped his side to a 32–25 win to qualify for their second ever final. Kriel started the final on the right wing for South Africa as they the match 20–21 to <a href="England%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> to finish the competition in second spot.
Kriel made thirteen appearances for the s during the <a href="2014%20Under-21%20Provincial%20Championship">2014 Under-21 Provincial Championship</a>. For the second year running, he scored two tries in a match against Western Province in a 44–30 win and also got a try in each of their matches against the s. The Blue Bulls U21s finished second on the log to Western Province, but – after beating the s 23–19 in the semi-final – won the final against Western Province in <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a>, running out 20–10 winners.
Varsity, Vodacom and Currie Cup (2015).
Kriel started the 2015 season by representing university side in the <a href="2015%20Varsity%20Cup">2015 Varsity Cup</a> competition. He scored tries in four different matches as UP Tuks topped the log after the round robin stage. He scored his fifth try of the competition in their semi-final match against , but it wasn't enough to prevent the team from <a href="Potchefstroom">Potchefstroom</a> winning the match 29–28 to progress to the final, eliminating UP Tuks. At the conclusion of the competition, Kriel was initially named in a Varsity Cup Dream Team to play a friendly against the <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">South African Under-20s</a>, but was subsequently withdrawn from the squad.
Instead, he was included in the squad for the <a href="2015%20Vodacom%20Cup">2015 Vodacom Cup</a> competition. He made his domestic first class debut in <a href="Windhoek">Windhoek</a>, starting the Blue Bulls' 44–0 victory over <a href="Namibia">Namibia</a>n side . He also started a further four matches for the Blue Bulls, which included their quarter final victory over a and their 6–10 defeat to in the semi-final.
Kriel played two matches for the s in the <a href="2015%20Under-21%20Provincial%20Championship%20Group%20A">2015 Under-21 Provincial Championship Group A</a> before being promoted to the senior squad for the <a href="2015%20Currie%20Cup%20Premier%20Division">2015 Currie Cup Premier Division</a>. He was named on the bench for their Round Three match against .
Stormers / Western Province.
At the start of 2017, Kriel moved to <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a>, where he joined the <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> team and the <a href="Currie%20Cup">Currie Cup</a> team.
Personal.
Kriel is the twin brother of <a href="Jesse%20Kriel">Jesse Kriel</a>, both brothers are professional South African rugby players and the great-grandson of John Hodgson (1909-1970), who played 15 games for the <a href="British%20and%20Irish%20Lions">British and Irish Lions</a> in the 1930s.
